channel.title: NYT > U.S. > Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pirro Threatens Jail Time for Lawful Gun Owners Who Travel to D.C. With Firearms
item.description: The remarks by Jeannine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, prompted swift pushback from the Republican Party’s pro-Second Amendment wing.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeanine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, in November.

item.title: Trump Says He’s Only Renovating the Kennedy Center
item.description: Even though President Trump held a movie premiere for his wife’s new film there last week, he said the state of the building was “actually sort of dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Julia Jacobs and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement raised questions about whether President Trump has the power to unilaterally shut down and renovate the Kennedy Center.

item.title: H.H.S. to Expand Faith-Based Addiction Programs for Homeless
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said addiction is a “spiritual disease” that calls out for the involvement of religious organizations.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, said the federal government would open funding opportunities to faith-based organizations that hold to evidence-based standards.

item.title: DOJ Failed to Address Press Law in Application to Search Washington Post Reporter’s Home
item.description: The Justice Department did not address a 1980 law that generally bars warrants for reporting material when it sought to seize a Washington Post reporter’s devices, an unsealed filing shows.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: First Amendment scholars say a search of a Washington Post reporter’s home appears to be unprecedented.

item.title: Why Texas Is the Wildest Story in U.S. Politics Right Now
item.description: First came a remarkable State Senate upset. Next up: two high-octane U.S. Senate primaries.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Rehmet, a Democrat, won an upset victory in a Texas State Senate special election last weekend.

item.title: Immigration Officers in Minneapolis Will Wear Body Cameras, Noem Says
item.description: The change comes as the federal government has provided accounts of fatal shootings that have sometimes conflicted with local officials and witness videos.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents and a protester in a confrontation in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Maryland Moves to Give Democrats Extra House Seat, but Big Hurdles Remain
item.description: The state’s House of Delegates passed a new map that would be likely to eliminate Maryland’s lone remaining Republican seat in the U.S. House, but the State Senate may well block the measure.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Jonathan Newton for The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Democratic-led push to redraw Maryland’s congressional maps is part of a nationwide effort by Democrats to keep pace in a redistricting arms race set off by Republicans in Texas last summer.

item.title: Trump Presses House G.O.P. to Back Deal to Reopen Government
item.description: Some hard-line House Republicans have balked at the deal Senate Democrats struck with President Trump to fund the government, complicating its path to enactment.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson will be able to afford just one defection on any party-line vote if all members are present.

item.title: Justice Dept. Sidelines Ed Martin as Chief of Weaponization Group
item.description: The move represents a consolidation of the authority of the deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche, in bringing Mr. Martin’s operation inside his office.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ed Martin, known by the self-bestowed moniker “Eagle Ed,” will retain his title as the Justice Department’s pardon attorney.

item.title: U.S. Military Tells Alaska and N.C. Troops to Stand Down on Possible Minnesota Deployment
item.description: More than 1,500 active-duty troops had been on standby to deploy to Minnesota, but were quietly taken off heightened alert over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands marched in streets of Minneapolis on Friday to protest the federal immigration crackdown. Over the weekend, Northern Command quietly ordered the active-duty troops on standby to stand down.

item.title: Dan Bongino, Former Deputy F.B.I. Director, Returns to Podcasting
item.description: Mr. Bongino, who spent nine months at the agency, spoke freely about the Epstein files and more as he returned to the land of “sound bites.”
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Bongino attending the Memorial Service for Charlie Kirk in 2025. He resigned from the F.B.I. last month.

item.title: Trump, in an Escalation, Calls for Republicans to ‘Nationalize’ Elections
item.description: The comments, made on a conservative podcast, follow a string of moves from his administration to try to exert more control over American elections.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has long been fixated on the false claim that voter fraud is rampant in the United States.

item.title: Trump Is Said to Have Dropped Demand for Cash From Harvard
item.description: Hours after The Times reported that President Trump had lowered the bar for a deal, he denied backtracking and made new threats against Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard has faced internal pressure for months from faculty, students and alumni who view President Trump as an authoritarian and any deal as an act of capitulation.

item.title: Some Federal Workers Furloughed in Partial Government Shutdown
item.description: Some of the affected agencies announced sweeping furloughs, while others tapped reserve funds to get through what they expected to be a short shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of the federal government closed over the weekend because of a lapse of funding for major agencies.

item.title: N.I.H. Worker Who Criticized Trump Seeks Whistle-Blower Protection
item.description: Jenna Norton, a National Institutes of Health employee, has been an outspoken critic of the administration’s research cuts and has been on paid leave.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz/Reuters
item.media:description: Jenna Norton last spring organized The Bethesda Declaration, a public letter that denounced what its authors viewed as the administration’s dismantling of the federal biomedical research apparatus.

item.title: Measles Hits ICE Family Detention Center in Texas
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security has imposed a quarantine on a family detention center in Dilley, Texas, after two detainees contracted the disease.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Brenda BazáN/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Dilley Immigration Processing Center is about 70 miles south of San Antonio and is currently the main detention center in the country that houses families, including young children.

item.title: Trump Unveils $12 Billion Critical Minerals Stockpile
item.description: The “Project Vault” initiative is intended to reduce U.S. reliance on China for key technology components.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Steve Marcus/Reuters
item.media:description: A rare earth mine in Mountain Pass, Calif. The United States is working to develop its own supply chain for critical minerals.

item.title: Judge Bars Further Changes to George Washington’s Philadelphia House
item.description: The Interior Department removed placards and videos about Washington’s involvement with slavery. A new court ruling blocks further changes, for now.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local teachers last month taped signs that read “history is real” on a blank wall where signs about slavery were removed at Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia.

item.title: Deal to Reopen Government on Shaky Ground in the House
item.description: Some hard-line House Republicans have balked at the deal Senate Democrats struck with President Trump to fund the government, complicating its path to enactment.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson taking questions on Capitol Hill in January.

item.title: Judge Again Blocks Policy Restricting Lawmakers’ Access to ICE Facilities
item.description: For a second time, Judge Jia M. Cobb found that a Trump administration policy requiring a seven-day waiting period was unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents outside Delaney Hall Detention Facility in Newark in June.

item.title: Trump Announces Initial Trade Deal With India, Cutting Tariffs to 18%
item.description: The agreement was short on details, but President Trump said India had promised to stop buying Russian oil and would buy more U.S. farm goods and other products.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, were spare on details in their announcements, and Mr. Modi did not mention whether his country would stop buying Russian oil, as Mr. Trump claimed.

item.title: Stars Bring ‘ICE OUT’ Pins and Fiery Speeches to a Political Grammys
item.description: Bad Bunny, Billie Eilish and Kehlani made strong statements about immigration on Sunday, while the host Trevor Noah drew President Trump’s ire.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Etienne Laurent/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: “No one is illegal on stolen land,” Billie Eilish said while accepting a Grammy on Sunday.

item.title: As Democrats Press Trump on ICE, Gallego and Pritzker Preview 2028 Pitches
item.description: Speaking at a party gathering in Nevada, the two politicians urged opposition to President Trump’s deportation agenda, while appearing to lay the groundwork for potential presidential runs.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Mikayla Whitmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ruben Gallego of Arizona, left, and Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois both spoke on Sunday at a Democratic Party fund-raiser in Las Vegas.

item.title: Clintons Capitulate on House Epstein Inquiry, Agreeing to Testify
item.description: Former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the ex-secretary of state, agreed to depositions they had long resisted days before the House was to vote to hold them in contempt.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ricky Carioti
item.media:description: Lawyers for former President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, made an offer for Mr. Clinton to testify before the House Oversight Committee after initially refusing.

item.title: Gabbard Arranges Trump Call With FBI Agents After Georgia Election Center Search
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, brokered the call and President Trump directly questioned frontline agents on the inquiry, The Times has learned.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum, Devlin Barrett and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Georgia Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election)
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director of national intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, wearing a coat and dark cap, at the Fulton County elections office in Fairburn, Ga., last week.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About the Partial Government Shutdown
item.description: A bipartisan spending deal couldn’t clear Congress in time to prevent a lapse in federal funding for some departments. The House must pass it to fully reopen the government.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis last month. Last-minute negotiations to keep the government running included starting talks on new limits on federal immigration agents.

item.title: What to Know About the Kennedy Center and Trump’s Campaign to Remake It
item.description: The center opened in 1971 and is one of America’s top cultural institutions. President Trump says he plans to transform the center to create a “new and spectacular” entertainment complex.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in January.

item.title: After His Democratic Victory in Texas, a New Working-Class Star Rises
item.description: Taylor Rehmet, a machinist and union leader, pulled off a stunning State Senate win in Fort Worth and its suburbs. He is among several political outsiders seeking office.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Rehmet, who won a State Senate race Saturday in Fort Worth and its suburbs.

item.title: Will the Spirit of 1976 Come to 2026?
item.description: Bicentennial celebrations across America were spirited and joyous. As the semiquincentennial approaches, there’s a different mood.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Pictorial Parade/Getty Images
item.media:description: Buster Smith, in Revolutionary garb, took part in an anti-big-business protest held by the People’s Bicentennial Commission at the Washington Monument on July 4, 1976.
